reversal of positions equals upheaval of social order
posture: YHWH announces a great reversal of fortunes
prophetic rhetoric attacks entrenched hierarchies
judgment is portrayed as leveling and reordering
instances.explanation: Spatial terms 'low' and 'high' are used metaphorically for lowly and exalted persons whose statuses God will reverse, exalting the low and humbling the high.

deliberation: The triple 'ruin' (עַוָּה עַוָּה עַוָּה) is an emphatic hyperbole for complete overturning, and the phrase 'until he comes to whom it rightfully belongs' alludes to rightful rule but is more allusive than clearly figurative.

instances.english_text: Ruin, an utter ruin I will make it (overturn, overturn, overturn it)
target: the existing royal and political order in Israel
the present state of the kingdom/city
ground: thoroughness and finality of dismantling
no stability or restoration left
emphatic completeness of ruin
posture: YHWH proclaims extreme judgment with intensifying language
prophet uses triple repetition as rhetorical hyperbole
audience is meant to feel that nothing of the old order will stand
instances.explanation: The thrice-repeated 'overturn/ruin' hyperbolically depicts a total and emphatic dismantling of the existing order, not just a mild change.

deliberation: The verse resumes the sword imagery, now directed at the Ammonites: an unsheathed, polished sword flashing like lightning, again a metaphor/metonymy for judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: חֶ֣רֶב חֶ֤רֶב פְּתוּחָה֙ לְטֶ֣בַח מְרוּטָ֔ה לְהָכִ֖יל לְמַ֥עַן בָּרָֽק
instances.english_text: O sword! O sword unsheathed for slaughter, polished to the utmost, to a flashing brilliance
target: God’s impending judgment on the Ammonites
their experience of invasion and slaughter
historical retribution on a foreign nation
ground: preparedness and lethal capacity
terrifying visual impact and speed
decisive destructive power
posture: YHWH addresses the sword rhetorically to dramatize judgment
prophet transfers the same sword-imagery used for Israel to Ammon
judgment appears as a vivid, lethal instrument now aimed outward
instances.explanation: The unsheathed, polished, lightning-like sword represents God’s judgment on Ammon, metonymically for invading forces and metaphorically for the nature of the destruction.

deliberation: The main focus is on false visions and divination; these are described straightforwardly as 'false' and 'deceitful'. The phrase about being wielded over the necks of the slain wicked is grim but essentially literal in battle imagery.

The sword is again addressed and told to 'return to its sheath' in the land of its origin. This personifies the sword and uses it metonymically for the martial power/judgment returning home for final judgment itself.

instances.hebrew_text: הָשַׁ֖ב אֶל־תַּעְרָ֑הּ ... בְּאֶ֥רֶץ מְכֻרוֹתַ֖יִךְ אֶשְׁפֹּ֥ט אֹתָֽךְ
instances.english_text: Return it to its sheath! In the place where you were created, in the land of your origin, I will judge you
target: the hostile power symbolized by the sword (Ammonite strength)
foreign entity subject to God’s judgment
vehicle: a sword being put back into its sheath in its homeland
weapon returning to its point of origin
ground: end of active use and withdrawal from aggression
return to the source for accountability
tool and user both brought under judgment
posture: YHWH now judges the very instrument of previous violence
prophet personifies the sword-nation as returning home to face trial
judgment imagery turns back on the aggressor
instances.explanation: The sword is personified and ordered back to its sheath in its land of origin, metonymically representing the Ammonite power being withdrawn and then judged on its own soil.

deliberation: Two overlapping metaphors: 'I will pour out my indignation' (wrath as a liquid) and 'with the fire of my wrath I will blow upon you' (wrath as fire fanned by breath). I treat this as one composite wrath-as-substance/fire metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשָׁפַכְתִּ֤י עָלַ֙יִךְ֙ זַעְמִ֔י בְּאֵ֥שׁ עֶבְרָתִ֖י אָפִ֣יחַ עָלָ֑יִךְ
instances.english_text: I will pour out My indignation upon you, I will blow upon you with the fire of My wrath
target: God’s exercise of judgment on the nation
experience of being punished by divine anger
vehicle: liquid indignation poured out and fire of wrath fanned by breath
substance and blaze directed at a target
ground: overwhelming, engulfing nature of anger
consuming, destructive effect of wrath
active direction and intensification by God
posture: YHWH portrays His wrath as a tangible, powerful force
prophet uses visceral imagery to show judgment’s violence
audience is meant to fear being engulfed by divine anger
instances.explanation: God’s anger is conceptualized as both a liquid poured and a fire blown upon the people, a vivid metaphor for the overwhelming, consuming character of His judgment.

deliberation: The central image is 'you shall be fuel for the fire', a metaphor for being entirely consumed in judgment. The blood sinking into the earth is grim but essentially literal.

instances.english_text: You shall be fuel for the fire
vehicle: wood or other matter feeding flames
ground: being entirely consumed and destroyed
serving only to intensify the destructive blaze
no remaining substance or status
posture: YHWH portrays the judged as only feeding the destructive fire of judgment
prophet uses annihilation imagery to emphasize severity
audience faces the prospect of being utterly used up in wrath
instances.explanation: The people are likened to fuel for a fire, a metaphor for their being completely consumed and annihilated by divine judgment.
